APT: Adaptive Pruning and Tuning Pretrained Language Models for Efficient Training and Inference
[ APT: Adaptive Pruning and Tuning Pretrained Language Models for
Efficient Training and Inference
equal*
Bowen Zhaoxxx Hannaneh Hajishirzixxx,yyy Qingqing Cao INLINEFORM0 zzz
xxxUniversity of Washington yyyAllen Institute for Artificial Intelligence zzz INLINEFORM0 Apple, work done at the University of Washington
Bowen Zhaobowen98@uw.edu Qingqing Caoqicao@apple.com
Machine Learning, ICML
]
Fine-tuning and inference with large Language Models (LM) are generally known to be expensive. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning over pretrained LMs reduces training memory by updating a small number of LM parameters but does not improve inference efficiency. Structured pruning improves LM inference efficiency by removing consistent parameter blocks, yet often increases training memory and time. To improve both training and inference efficiency, we introduce that adaptively prunes and tunes parameters for the LMs. At the early stage of fine-tuning, dynamically adds salient tuning parameters for fast and accurate convergence while discarding unimportant parameters for efficiency. Compared to baselines, our experiments show that maintains up to 98% task performance when pruning 60% of the parameters in RoBERTa and T5 models. APT also preserves 86.4% of LLaMA models' performance with 70% parameters remaining. Furthermore, speeds up LMs' fine-tuning by up to 8 INLINEFORM0 and reduces large LMs' memory training footprint by up to 70%. Our code and models are publicly available at https://github.com/ROIM1998/APT.

Fine-tuning and inference with large Language Models (LM) are generally known to be expensive. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning over pretrained LMs reduces training memory by updating a small number of LM parameters but does not improve inference efficiency. Structured pruning improves LM inference efficiency by removing consistent parameter blocks, yet often increases training memory and time. To improve both training and inference efficiency, we introduce that adaptively prunes and tunes parameters for the LMs. At the early stage of fine-tuning, dynamically adds salient tuning parameters for fast and accurate convergence while discarding unimportant parameters for efficiency. Compared to baselines, our experiments show that maintains up to 98% task performance when pruning 60% of the parameters in RoBERTa and T5 models. APT also preserves 86.4% of LLaMA models' performance with 70% parameters remaining. Furthermore, speeds up LMs' fine-tuning by up to 8 INLINEFORM0 and reduces large LMs' memory training footprint by up to 70%. Our code and models are publicly available at https://github.com/ROIM1998/APT.

body_text.text: Fine-tuning language models (LMs) BIBREF0 , BIBREF1 , BIBREF2 is an essential paradigm to adapt them to downstream tasks BIBREF3 , BIBREF4 . Increasing the parameter scale of LMs improves model performance BIBREF5 , but incurs significant training and inference costs. For instance, a 13B LLaMA model BIBREF6 costs about 100GB memory for fine-tuning and 30GB for inference with float16 datatype. It is important to improve the training and inference efficiency of LM for practical applications.

Parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods (PEFT, summarized in tab:preliminary-summary) BIBREF16 , BIBREF17 reduce the memory consumption of LM fine-tuning via updating a small number of parameters. However, PEFT models do not improve inference efficiency because the LM size remains the same or even increases after fine-tuning. For instance, LoRA BIBREF8 tunes low-rank decomposed linear layers parallel to frozen parameters to reduce training memory but takes longer to converge BIBREF18 . On the other hand, structured pruning BIBREF13 , BIBREF12 , BIBREF19 improves inference efficiency by removing blocks of parameters such as attention heads and feed-forward neurons in Transformer LMs, showing more inference speedup than sparse unstructured pruning methods BIBREF20 , BIBREF21 , BIBREF10 . However, training pruned LMs takes extra time to converge and incurs high memory, substantially diminishing LMs' accessibility in usage scenarios with limited computational resources.

Integrating structured pruning and PEFT could increase both training and inference efficiency. However, existing research BIBREF22 indicates that combining PEFT and structured pruning, such as applying structured pruning over LoRA-tuned models, causes noticeable performance loss and extra training costs. It remains challenging to prune LMs accurately using limited training resources.

In this paper, we develop an efficient fine-tuning approach named that A daptively selects model parameters for P runing and fine- T uning. combines the benefits of PEFT and structured pruning to make fine-tuning and inference more efficient. Our intuition is that pre-trained LM parameters contain general knowledge, but their importance to downstream tasks varies. Therefore, we can remove the parameters irrelevant to the fine-tuning task in the early training stage. Early-removing these parameters improves training and inference efficiency while not substantially hurting model accuracy BIBREF23 , BIBREF24 , BIBREF25 . Meanwhile, continuously adding more parameters for fine-tuning can improve LM performance because task-specific skills live in a subset of LM parameters BIBREF26 , BIBREF27 .

More specifically, learns the pruning masks via an outlier-aware salience scoring function to remove irrelevant LM parameter blocks and adds more tuning parameters during fine-tuning according to tuning layer importance. To make training more efficient, the salience scoring function is lightweight and causes little runtime and memory overhead. Combined with our self-distillation technique that shares teacher and student parameters, can accurately prune an LM with less training time and lower memory usage.

Experimental results show that prunes RoBERTa and T5 base models 8 INLINEFORM0 faster than the LoRA plus pruning baseline while reaching 98.0% performance with 2.4 INLINEFORM1 speedup and 78.1% memory consumption during inference. When pruning large LMs like LLaMA, costs only 30% memory compared to the state-of-the-art pruning method and still maintains 86.4% performance with 70% parameters. Our ablation study in sec:ablation indicates the effectiveness of adaptive pruning and tuning. It also demonstrates that efficient distillation with APT adapter substantially recovers small LMs' performance while outlier-aware salience scoring prunes large LMs more accurately. Our analysis in sec:analysis demonstrates that controlled adaptive tuning with early pruning during fine-tuning improves LM end-task accuracy better with less training time and memory costs.

PEFT methods aim to tune LMs with limited resources by updating a small number of parameters BIBREF28 , mainly falling into three categories: selective, additive, and dynamic. Selective methods focus on tuning a subset of parameters in LMs with pre-defined rules BIBREF29 or importance metrics BIBREF30 , BIBREF31 . Additive methods tune injected layer modules BIBREF16 , BIBREF7 or embeddings BIBREF32 , BIBREF17 . For example, LoRA BIBREF8 tunes low-rank decomposed layers to avoid inference cost overhead. However, LoRA keeps the tuning layer shapes static without dynamic adjustments. Dynamic methods BIBREF33 adjust tuning parameters during training. For instance, AdaLoRA BIBREF9 gradually reduces tuning parameters but does not benefit inference efficiency. Compared to these methods, adaptively adjusts the pruning and tuning parameters simultaneously, improving training and inference efficiency.

Model compression methods like quantization and pruning boost inference efficiency. Quantization aims to reduce LMs' memory consumption via converting parameters to low-bit data types BIBREF34 , BIBREF35 , BIBREF36 . However, despite reducing LM's memory consumption, the speedup benefits of quantization require specific framework support, which limits their adaptability. Pruning BIBREF37 , BIBREF20 , BIBREF38 , BIBREF39 aims to discard unimportant parameters in LMs for inference efficiency. Unstructured pruning BIBREF10 prunes sparse parameters in LMs, which requires dedicated hardware support for efficiency improvements. Meanwhile, structured pruning BIBREF11 , BIBREF12 prunes consistent blocks in transformer layers (MHA heads, FFN neurons, and model dimensions) for ubiquitous inference efficiency gains. Such pruning often uses knowledge distillation BIBREF40 , which causes more training costs. Post-training pruning BIBREF13 , BIBREF41 aims to prune fine-tuned models with limited extra costs but requires initialization from fully fine-tuned models. Moreover, task-agnostic pruning BIBREF42 , BIBREF19 cannot achieve on-par performance with task-specific pruning.

Combining model compression and PEFT might achieve both training and inference efficiency improvements: QLoRA BIBREF43 and QA-LoRA BIBREF44 bring quantization and LoRA together for large LM tuning. SPA BIBREF14 combines structured pruning and Compacter BIBREF45 , yet suffers substantial performance loss. CPET BIBREF22 leverages different task-agnostic model compression methods together with LoRA and knowledge distillation, but the performance loss becomes notable specifically when structured pruning is applied. PST BIBREF46 and LRP BIBREF15 also explored the combination of LoRA and pruning, yet their performance degradations are also substantial because their tuning parameters are static. In contrast, identifies tuning and pruning parameters based on their salience in fine-tuning, which can improve training and inference efficiency under a new paradigm with minimal performance loss.

Our goal is to improve the training and inference efficiency of pretrained LM while maintaining task performance. Intuitively, tuning fewer parameters leads to smaller training memory footprints and shorter time per training step; models with fewer parameters also run faster with less memory footprint during inference but come with task performance degradation. We aim to find the optimal parameters for training and inference without sacrificing task performance.

We formally define the problem objective as minimizing the task loss INLINEFORM0 under the constraint that the total LM parameter size INLINEFORM1 reaches a target sparsity (defined as the ratio of the number of parameters pruned to the original LM) INLINEFORM2 after INLINEFORM3 training steps. For each training step INLINEFORM4 , the sparsity of the LM remains above INLINEFORM5 while the number of tuning parameters is below INLINEFORM6 . We control the pruning masks INLINEFORM7 and tuning ranks INLINEFORM8 to satisfy these constraints. We describe the optimization process as:

Based on eq:problem, a higher target sparsity INLINEFORM0 improves inference efficiency with fewer FLOPs and memory usage but sacrifices performance. Increasing INLINEFORM1 when INLINEFORM2 also improves training efficiency. Besides, tuning more parameters with larger INLINEFORM3 costs more training memory but makes the model converge faster with better task performance. Our formulation supports task performance improvements together with training and inference efficiency by dynamically adjusting the LM parameters during fine-tuning.
We design A daptive P runing and T uning ( APT ) over LM parameters to allow efficient training and inference while maintaining task performance.

Summarized in the left of fig:elastic-adapter, existing pruning methods often neglect training costs where the number of tuning parameters is more than a parameter-efficient threshold with INLINEFORM0 , resulting in long training time and high memory consumption. Instead, to improve training efficiency, we prune LM parameters (increase INLINEFORM1 ) during early training when INLINEFORM2 while keeping INLINEFORM3 to reduce training costs. In addition, we add tuning parameters (increase INLINEFORM4 ) in early training to effectively mitigate the degradation of LM's performance due to pruning.

Overview. fig:elastic-adapter shows the overview of our method that incorporates our new APT adapter for pruning and tuning. Our intuition is that pruning LMs during early fine-tuning will not hurt their task performance while reducing training and inference costs. Meanwhile, unlike existing adapters like LoRA BIBREF8 that use fixed tuning parameters, APT adapters dynamically add tuning parameters to accelerate LM convergence with superior task performance. We first introduce the architecture of APT adapters in sec:apt. We then describe how we prune LM parameters at early fine-tuning with low cost in sec:apt-prune and adaptively tune LMs to recover task performance efficiently in sec:apt-tune. Additionally, we explain our self-knowledge distillation technique that improves pruned LM's task performance with limited training expense in sec:momentum.

We build the APT adapter architecture over LoRA, but the key difference is that APT adapter supports dynamic LM pruning and tuning. Assuming an APT adapter projects the input INLINEFORM0 to the output INLINEFORM1 , we design binary pruning masks ( INLINEFORM2 for input and INLINEFORM3 for output) and dynamic ranks INLINEFORM4 in APT adapter to control the total and tuning LM parameters during fine-tuning, respectively. Specifically, with tuning parameters INLINEFORM5 and INLINEFORM6 , APT adapter INLINEFORM7 is denoted as:

The parameter block is pruned when the multiplying mask is set to 0 and retained when set to 1. In the meantime, during fine-tuning, we dynamically increase INLINEFORM2 for the weight matrices INLINEFORM3 and INLINEFORM4 . Compared to LoRA, APT adapters can be more efficient due to more adaptive pruning and tuning over LM parameters.

In transformer-based LM fine-tuning, we add APT adapters in queries and values of multi-head attention (MHA) layers. We also add APT adapter in feed-forward network (FFN) layers when fine-tuning smaller models like RoBERTa and T5 for fast training convergence. In these cases, INLINEFORM0 prunes transformers' hidden dimension and INLINEFORM1 prunes attention heads in MHA and internal neurons in FFN layers. By learning the pruning masks and adjusting the ranks dynamically in the APT adapter, we can achieve the goal defined in sec:formulation where the tuning parameter number INLINEFORM2 increases to maintain task performance and the LM parameter size INLINEFORM3 decreases to support more efficient training and inference. Next, we describe the adaptive pruning and tuning procedures in detail.

body_text.section: Adaptive Pruning and Tuning::Low-cost Adaptive LM Pruning ( 𝒜 P \mathcal {A}_{\text{P}} )

body_text.text: To benefit the efficiency of LM training and inference, adaptively prunes LM parameters since the start of fine-tuning. The problem is finding the parameters to be pruned and discarding them without hurting training stability. Given a task, we compute the outlier-aware salience score of parameter blocks at each early-training step when INLINEFORM0 . Afterward, we use a fast search algorithm to determine the parameters to be pruned, and then we update their binary pruning masks accordingly. The upper-right of fig:elastic-adapter shows this adaptive pruning procedure.
body_text.section: Adaptive Pruning and Tuning::Low-cost Adaptive LM Pruning ( 𝒜 P \mathcal {A}_{\text{P}} )

body_text.text: Outlier-aware salience scoring of LM parameters. When determining the influence of pruning parameters on the LM performance for fine-tuning tasks, the key idea is to compute the outlier-aware salience scores of LM activations to consider both tuning and frozen parameters. In detail, salience is defined as the magnitude of parameters' weight-gradient production from previous works BIBREF10 , where

body_text.text: However, since the frozen weights' gradients are unreachable in PEFT settings, we compute the salience as the magnitude of the product of activations and their gradients. Additionally, we compress the activation and gradients by summing along batches before production to further reduce the training memory consumption. On the other hand, block outlier parameters play a crucial role in task-specific capabilities, as previous quantization methods suggest BIBREF35 , BIBREF36 . Such effects brought by outlier parameters will be averaged if salience is only measured on the block level. To keep more outlier parameters in the pruned LMs, we combine the salience score above and the kurtosis FOOTREF12 of the activation together. Therefore, given the supervised finetuning dataset INLINEFORM0 , the outlier-aware salience score INLINEFORM1 is defined as:

body_text.text: As using PEFT methods to fine-tune pruned LMs causes notable performance decrease (illustrated in tab:small-model-results and tab:ablate-paramalloc), we aim to dynamically add tuning parameters in LM fine-tuning to improve the model's end-task performance. However, since more tuning parameters will consume extra training time and memory, we want to add parameters in a controlled way, where new parameters are only added to task-sensitive adapters. As a result, we can recover pruned LMs' performance with reasonable training costs. In detail, we first calculate the salience of each adapter to determine their importance. Next, we select the top-half adapters after sorting them with salience and add their parameters by increasing their INLINEFORM0 .

body_text.text: Salience scoring of APT adapter. Since gradients of tuning parameters information are available when determining the layer salience, we can first calculate each tuning parameter's salience with eq:salience. Then, we define the salience of an APT adapter as the summation of the parameter salience scores in INLINEFORM0 , denoted as INLINEFORM1 , to represent each tuning APT adapter's importance FOOTREF17 . Given the calculated INLINEFORM2 for each APT adapter, we can then decide where to add new tuning parameters to efficiently improve the pruned LM's task accuracy.

body_text.text: As shown in tab:ablate-paramalloc, training pruned LM without knowledge distillation causes significant end-task performance drops. Therefore, we use knowledge distillation in to recover the pruned LM's performance. Still, existing strategies require a fully trained teacher model being put into the GPU with the student during distillation, causing high training time and memory. To avoid extra training costs, we keep duplicating the tuning student layers as teachers during fine-tuning to reduce total training time. Meanwhile, frozen parameters are shared between the student and teacher model during training to reduce memory consumption. We edit the distillation objective in CoFi BIBREF12 as

body_text.section: Adaptive Pruning and Tuning::Efficient Self-Knowledge Distillation

body_text.text: To evaluate the training and inference efficiency gains of , we compare it with the combined use of PEFT with pruning and distillation baselines. We first describe the natural language understanding and generation tasks targeting different LM backbones, then the setup of baselines and . We then report task performance, speed, and memory usage for training and inference costs.

We apply to BERT BIBREF0 , RoBERTa BIBREF1 , T5 BIBREF2 FOOTREF23 , and LLaMA BIBREF6 . For BERT, RoBERTa, and T5 models, we train and evaluate on SST2 and MNLI datasets from the GLUE benchmark BIBREF49 and report the dev set accuracy. We also train and evaluate INLINEFORM0 on SQuAD v2.0 BIBREF50 and report the dev set F1 score. For T5 models, we also fine-tune them on CNN/DM BIBREF51 and report the ROUGE 1/2/L scores. Meanwhile, We use the GPT-4 generated Alpaca dataset BIBREF52 to fine-tune large LLaMA models and evaluate them with the lm-eval-harness package BIBREF53 on four tasks from the Open LLM Leaderboard, namely 25-shot ARC BIBREF54 , 10-shot HellaSwag BIBREF55 , 5-shot MMLU BIBREF56 , and zero-shot TruthfulQA BIBREF57 .
We validate the efficiency benefits of for both training and inference by comparing with PEFT, pruning, and distillation methods, along with their combinations.

LoRA+Prune : a post-training pruning method over on LoRA-tuned LMs. We use Mask Tuning BIBREF13 , a state-of-the-art post-training structured pruning method based on fisher information. Due to that post-training pruning performs poorly on high-sparsity settings, we retrain the pruned LM after pruning to recover its performance.

Prune+Distill : knowledge distillation has been proved to be a key technique in recovering pruned LMs' task accuracy. In particular, we use the state-of-the-art pruning plus distillation method called CoFi BIBREF12 which uses INLINEFORM0 regularization for pruning plus dynamic layer-wise distillation objectives. We only compare to CoFi with RoBERTa models since the training memory usage of CoFi is too high for larger LMs.

LoRA+Prune+Distill : to reduce the training memory consumption in pruning and distillation, a simple baseline is to conduct CoFi pruning and distillation but with LoRA parameters tuned only. More specifically, only the INLINEFORM0 module and LoRA parameters are tunable under this setting.

LLMPruner BIBREF19 : LLMPruner is the state-of-the-art task-agnostic pruning method on LLaMA that prunes its blocks or channels based on salience metrics while using LoRA for fast performance recovery. We compare to LLMPruner with fine-tuning on the same GPT-4 generated Alpaca data for fair comparisons.

We also compare to PST BIBREF46 and LRP BIBREF15 , which are the state-of-the-art parameter-efficient unstructured and structured pruning methods on INLINEFORM0 model. We leave these results in sec:appendix-additional-exp.
We evaluate and baselines on training and inference efficiency, measured in runtime memory and time consumption as follows:

Training Efficiency Metrics : we report relative training peak memory (Train. Mem.) and relative training speed measured by time to accuracy (TTA FOOTREF26 ) BIBREF58 compared to full finetuning. For fair comparisons, we consider the training time of the teacher model plus the student for methods using knowledge distillation.
Inference Efficiency Metrics : we report the inference peak memory (Inf. Mem.) and the relative speedup (Inf. Speed) based on throughput (data processed per second) for inference efficiency.

Both training and evaluation are conducted on a single A100 GPU. The inference test batch size is 128 for small models while 32 and 4 for LLaMA 7B and 13B models, respectively. We demonstrate detailed training and evaluation setups/implementations in appendix:hyper-param.

Overview We demonstrate the end-task performance of comparing to fine-tuning (FT), LoRA-tuning (LoRA), and pruning baselines in tab:small-model-results and tab:llama-7b-results. Overall, up to 99% of fine-tuned LM's task accuracy is maintained when pruning RoBERTa and T5 models leaving 40% parameters, with only about 70% training memory consumption than fine-tuning. When pruning LLaMA2-7B models with 70% parameters remaining, recovers 86.4% task performance on average, together with only 75.8% training memory usage than LoRA-tuning. Furthermore, also significantly reduces end-task performance and training costs compared to the pruning and distillation baselines. The detailed comparisons are shown as follows.

speeds up RoBERTa and T5 training 8×\times and reduces training memory costs to 30% in LLaMA pruning compared to LoRA+Prune baseline. Shown in tab:small-model-results, when pruning RoBERTa models to 60% sparsity, converges INLINEFORM0 faster than the LoRA+Prune baseline with consuming similar GPU memory. also prunes T5 models 8.2 INLINEFORM1 faster than the LoRA+Prune baseline. The reason is that adaptively prunes task-irrelevant parameters during training, reducing memory and per-step training time. Adding parameters in salient tuning layers also accelerates LM convergence. Also, costs less than 24GB of memory when pruning 30% parameters in LLaMA2-7B models before tuning, which can be easily adapted to the consumer-level GPUs. In contrast, LLM-Pruner costs about 80GB memory when pruning the LLaMA 7B model FOOTREF28 .

achieves 2.5%-9.9% higher task performance than the LoRA+Prune baseline with the same pruning sparsities. Presented in tab:small-model-results and tab:llama-7b-results , when RoBERTa, T5, and LLaMA models, regardless of size, consistently reach higher task performance than the LoRA+Prune. With similar inference speedup and memory when pruning RoBERTa models, reaches 2.5% more end-task performance on average. When pruning T5 models under the 60% sparsity, the task performance achieved by is 5.1% better than the LoRA+Prune baseline. However, the inference efficiency reached by (1.3 INLINEFORM0 speedup and 81.5% memory cost) is worse than the LoRA+Prune baseline (2.1 INLINEFORM1 speedup and 73.4% memory cost). This is because can adaptively prune more decoder parameters, which are also computationally cheaper than encoder parameters (due to shorter output sequence length) but relatively useless for classification tasks. For LLaMA2-7B model pruning with 70% sparsity, outperforms LLMPruner with 16.5% and the LoRA+Prune baseline with 9.9%, where the inference efficiency improvements of is slightly better than both LoRA+Prune and LLMPruner baselines.

reaches on-par performance with the Prune+Distill baseline given the same pruning sparsity but trains 2.5×\times faster and costs only 41.6% memory. Compared to the Prune+Distill baseline, results in comparable task accuracy (0.9 point drop in MNLI and same in SST2). At the same time, with similar inference efficiency achieved, costs only 41.6% training memory and converges 2.5 INLINEFORM0 than the Prune+Distill baseline. This is because of the self-distillation technique in where no separated teacher model is required in pruning LMs. Moreover, achieves better task performance than the LoRA+Prune+Distill baseline as well, with less training time and memory consumption. These results demonstrate that successfully tackles the problem where simply combining PEFT and pruning hurts pruned LM's task accuracy and training efficiency.

We further show the task performance changing trajectory with different pruning sparsities in fig:prune-tradeoff. achieves superior inference speedup with less inference memory consumption than baselines targeting the same task performance. Compared to the LoRA+Prune baseline, when pruning RoBERTa models targeting similar task accuracy, is 21.8% faster in inference and is 7% more memory-efficient. For T5 model pruning with 97% of dense model performance, results in 62.7% more inference speedup with 24.8% more inference memory reduction compared to the LoRA+Prune baseline. When pruning large LLaMA2-7B models, speedup is 6.7% more and reduces 9.2% more inference memory than the LoRA+Prune baseline, maintaining over 85% task performance of the dense model.

We evaluate the impact of different components in by removing the adaptive pruning ( INLINEFORM0 ), adaptive tuning ( INLINEFORM1 ), and self-distillation ( INLINEFORM2 ). Besides end-task performance, we also report the training efficiency metrics for each ablation.

Adaptive pruning (𝒜 P \mathcal {A}_{\text{P}}) We demonstrate the ablation of adaptive pruning (w/o INLINEFORM0 ) for RoBERTa models in tab:ablate-paramalloc and LLaMA models in tab:llama-ablation. In these cases, we only train LMs with adaptive tuning strategies with supervised fine-tuning objectives without distillation. In such settings, w/o INLINEFORM1 can be recognized as a PEFT method with tuning parameters' sizes adaptively changing during fine-tuning. Hence, the inference efficiency of the trained LMs are the same as full fine-tuning and LoRA. Without pruning, the task performance of RoBERTa reaches 94.4 for SST2 and 87.5 for MNLI (99.8% fine-tuned LM performance on average). The average performance of the LLaMA model also achieves 96.6% to its LoRA-tuned counterpart. In addition, we surprisingly find that the RoBERTA training speed with w/o INLINEFORM2 is even 21% faster than full fine-tuning while costing only 62.2% memory. In the meantime, the training memory cost of w/o INLINEFORM3 in LLaMA tuning is higher than LoRA. The reason is that the tuning parameter number of will grow larger than static LoRA-tuning. This ablation demonstrates that adaptive pruning is essential in reducing the training memory consumption of LLaMA model fine-tuning, besides benefiting model inference efficiency.

Adaptive tuning (𝒜 T \mathcal {A}_{\text{T}}) In tab:ablate-paramalloc, we show results of ablating adaptive tuning (w/o INLINEFORM0 ) where the tuning parameters are static when pruning RoBERTa models. Without INLINEFORM1 , the model's performance decreases to 93.2/84.4, leading to a similar performance as the LoRA+Prune baseline (93.0/84.0). Moreover, equally increasing parameters across all layers instead of adding parameters based on salience notably hurts the task accuracy (84.4 on MNLI compared to 86.4). At the same time, INLINEFORM2 helps the model converge 16% faster than static LoRA training. For ablation results in LLaMA models shown in tab:llama-ablation, we observe that INLINEFORM3 recovers the model performance under 50% pruning setting (38.2 compared to 35.8). However, the difference under 70% pruning is insignificant. Meanwhile, if calculating the pruning parameter salience without using kurtosis to consider outliers parameters, the pruned LM's performance substantially drops from 50.0 to 38.1. We conclude that INLINEFORM4 substantially improves LM training speed and end-task performance. For large LLaMA-based LM pruning, and outlier parameters are essential to recovering the pruned large LLaMA-based models' capabilities.

Self-distillation (𝒟 S \mathcal {D}_{\text{S}}) Shown in tab:ablate-paramalloc, tuning adapters dynamically without distillation objectives gets 1.35 worse task accuracy on average. However, pruning RoBERTa models without self-distillation is 22.5% faster and costs 11.7% less training memory. This result indicates the effectiveness of leveraging knowledge distillation to recover pruned LM performance, but conducting distillation will result in extra training costs regarding both time and memory. Detailed comparisons of self-distillation and traditional, static distillation strategies are shown in appendix:distillation.

Besides the ablation study results demonstrated above, we show the detailed analysis of adaptive pruning and tuning's effect on LMs' end-task performance, training, and inference efficiency in sec:analysis.

Towards better performance gain and inference speedup of large LM in limited resource settings. By comparing tab:small-model-results to tab:llama-7b-results, we notice the performance gap in pruned LLaMA models is larger than smaller LMs because we use distillation-free settings in large LM pruning to reduce training memory consumption. One can improve performance-efficiency trade-offs with better memory-efficient distillation, parameter sharing, and re-allocation strategies. Furthermore, because of the hardware features of Ampere-architecture GPUs, layer dimensions divisible by 8 for FP16 and divisible by 16 for Int8 would reach more realistic speedups. One possible direction is to explore a higher level of structured pruning, for example, grouped neurons and dimensions, in LLMs.

Training could be unstable because of parameter shape changes. Since we adjust tuning parameters dynamically during training, newly initialized parameters are added to the model while existing parameters are pruned. We reset the optimizer every time after each parameter size changes to avoid stability issues, but this strategy might cause unstable training. Meanwhile, the time of selecting the teacher checkpoints during training highly affects the pruned model's performance, whereas non-converged or sparse teachers do not help in performance recovery. The pruned LMs' end-task accuracy could benefit from better and more stable strategies in adaptive pruning and tuning.

Could non-linear adapters perform better for performance recovery? To avoid inference time and memory overhead, we specifically adapt APT adapter to LoRA since the added tuning parameters can be merged after LMs' training. However, low-rank decomposition does not add more complexity to a LM, whereas the model's overall representation capacity doesn't increase. The adaptation with a wider range of adapters, such as Prefix-tuning BIBREF17 , HAdapters BIBREF16 , and Parallel-adapters BIBREF59 , could be better explored.

We design to adaptively identify LMs' pruning and tuning parameters during fine-tuning, improving both training and inference efficiency. prunes small LMs faster while pruning large LMs with less memory consumption. With using similar memory costs as LoRA, prunes small LMs 8 INLINEFORM0 faster than the LoRA plus pruning baseline. In large LM pruning, maintains 87% performance with only 30% pruning memory usage when 70% LM parameter retained. opens new directions to pruning LMs in fine-tuning for resource-limited settings, allowing wider usage of LMs in practical applications. In the future, we could adapt to more PEFT architectures and target better performance-efficiency trade-offs for billion-level large LMs. Meanwhile, we hope future research will continue to find efficient and accurate techniques to identify salient structures in LMs based on our formulated setting.

This paper introduces APT, a paradigm for improving the efficiency of training and inference in pre-trained LMs. While our primary goal is to advance machine learning, particularly in the efficiency of LMs and their applications, we recognize potential broader societal impacts. APT significantly reduces training and inference costs and contributes to lower resource consumption for a wide range of applications. This could have a positive environmental impact but might lead to potential model misuse due to lower resource requirements. Additionally, while APT does not introduce new ethical concerns, it might inherit existing issues in language models, for example, biases in training data. We explicitly ask users of APT to be aware of these risks and follow best practices in data selection and model monitoring to mitigate potential harms.

Our hyper-parameter settings are shown in tab:appendix-hyperparam. For GLUE task fine-tuning, we follow the hyper-parameter setting of CoFi BIBREF12 , separating the tasks into big (MNLI, SST2, QNLI, QQP) and small (MRPC, CoLA, RTE, STSB) based on the dataset size. For instruction tuning on the Alpaca dataset, we train the pruned model for 15 epochs after the pre-tuning pruning process to make sure they converge. However, in practice, such training epochs can be reduced. To adaptively increase the tuning parameters in the LM, at the start of fine-tuning, we initialize adapter ranks to 8, with salient layers' ranks linearly increased. The scaling factors are set as 2 statically. Since evaluating billion-level LLaMA models during instruction tuning with all evaluation tasks would be time-consuming, we did not do the TTA evaluation as small models. We do not conduct any hyper-parameters search for any training for fair comparison.

When pruning LMs with , following BIBREF12 , we first prune and train the LM with the self-distillation objective, and then fine-tune the pruned LM to recover its end-task performance. Given INLINEFORM0 pruning training steps in total, we set a pre-determined target sparsity INLINEFORM1 (defined as the ratio of pruned parameter size to the total parameter size) and use cubic scheduling to control the LM parameter size, where INLINEFORM2 . We adaptively increase the tuning parameters in the pruning stage but restrict them to a specific limit INLINEFORM3 at each training step INLINEFORM4 . Towards better training stability in LM pruning, we gradually decrease the pruning masks of pruned blocks by INLINEFORM5 instead of instantly setting them from ones to zeros. We also use the exponential moving-averaged salience in BIBREF9 when calculating the salience score during fine-tuning.

As addressed in sec:apt, we use the compressed weight-gradient production as the salience metric for identifying the tuning and pruning parameter blocks in LMs. Previous works BIBREF10 use salience score defined as the magnitude of the parameters' weight-gradient production, where given a linear layer INLINEFORM0 (we omit the bias term here for simplicity) in model parameters INLINEFORM1 trained on the objective INLINEFORM2 , the salience scoring function INLINEFORM3 is defined as:

For the details of the algorithm, we first sort all blocks by the salience density, defined as the block salience divided by the number of parameters in the block. For instance, given a RoBERTa-base model with the hidden dimension INLINEFORM0 , the number of transformer layers INLINEFORM1 , the number of attention heads INLINEFORM2 , and the number of FFN neurons INLINEFORM3 , we have:

Since the number of heads, neurons, and hidden dimensions is ever-changing during pruning, we re-calculate the density after executing each parameter size change. Meanwhile, for T5 and LLaMA-like models, the FFN layers are gated, consisting of up-, gate-, and down-projection linear layers. Therefore, the number of layers in FFN shall be three instead of two in these LMs. Furthermore, for encoder-decoder LMs like T5, the cross-attention layers in the decoder shall also be counted.

In this section, we further compare to existing parameter-efficient pruning methods, such as PST and LRP. In the meantime, we also show detailed results of pruning compared to the LoRA+Distill baseline with more tasks in the GLUE benchmark and LLaMA-2 13B model pruning results.

We compare with the state-of-the-art joint use of unstructured pruning BIBREF46 and structured pruning BIBREF15 with PEFT on INLINEFORM0 model, showing in tab:bert-additional-result. We can see that outperforms existing baselines in both 50% and 10% pruning density settings with a notable margin. The performance gain is credited to our more accurate pruning strategy considering frozen and tuning parameters. At the same time, our efficient self-distillation technique used in conjunction with salient parameters added in training also boosts performance recovery.
body_text.section: Additional Baseline Comparisons::Comparison to PST and LRP

body_text.text: We show the detailed comparison between and the LoRA+Distill baseline in tab:roberta-detailed-results. reaches superior task performance compared to the baseline in all seven GLUE tasks listed in the table, with on average 93.5% fine-tuned LM performance maintained, notably outperforming the joint use of LoRA and knowledge distillation. In particular, the results of STS-B cannot be reproduced when conducting CoFi distillation with LoRA parameters tuned only, so we exclude the comparison on STS-B. Among the other seven tasks in the GLUE benchmark, we find that tasks with relatively smaller dataset sizes, namely CoLA, MRPC, and RTE, reach superior performance gain when using . We conclude that this is because, compared to simple fine-tuning, knowledge distillation with salient parameters added in training is more robust and not prone to overfitting the training data.
body_text.section: Additional Baseline Comparisons::Further Comparison to LoRA+Distill

body_text.text: As shown in tab:llama-results, when pruning LLaMA-2 13B models, maintains 90.0% performance of the unpruned LoRA-tuned baseline. Compared to the pruning result on 7B models that maintain 86.4% dense model performance, better accuracies can be recovered in larger models (13B). At the same time, under the same pre-tuning pruning settings, performs better than the LLMPruner baseline on all four evaluation tasks, indicating the effectiveness of considering outlier parameters in large LM pruning. Nonetheless, the LoRA+Prune baseline reaches slightly better results than when pruning 13B models, illustrating that there is still room for improving pre-tuning pruning methods in future works. More specifically, among the four tasks we use for evaluating large LMs, TruthfulQA benefits the most from Alpaca fine-tuning. We can see that reaches superior results on TruthfulQA than existing baselines regardless of model size. The LM's capabilities on ARC and HellaSawg downgrade the most when pruning large LM before fine-tuning, implying possibilities of catastrophic forgetting in this paradigm.

We use fig:perf-efficiency-tradeoff to clearly show the LMs' end-task performance and efficiency tradeoffs between different tuning, pruning, and distillation baselines. We add several extra baselines to conduct more detailed comparisons between with existing PEFT, pruning, and distillation methods:

LoRA+Prune w/distill : we first use LoRA to fully converge a model on the task dataset, and then use Mask-Tuning BIBREF13 to prune the LM. Afterward, we utilize the converged model before pruning as the teacher model and distill its knowledge to the pruned student model with static knowledge distillation objectives.

LoRA+Prune w/o retrain : we use Mask-Tuning to prune a LoRA-tuned converged model but do not conduct any retraining to recover the pruned models' performance. Therefore, the LM's training time will be reduced, yet its performance is lower than the LoRA+Prune baseline.

With the same target sparsity in RoBERTa and LLaMA pruning setups, achieves on-par end-task performance with full fine-tuning and LoRA tuning baselines. Meanwhile, -tuned models reach similar or even better inference time and memory efficiency than existing baselines. -pruned T5 LMs' inference efficiency is slightly worse because more decoder parameters (with less computations happening) are pruned than the baselines. Moreover, when pruning RoBERTa and T5 models, achieves faster training time than all pruning and distillation baselines. Specifically, the training speed of in RoBERTa models is even higher than LoRA tuning without pruning. In LLaMA model pruning, costs significantly less training memory than both LLMPruner and LoRA+Prune baselines.

We further show the task performance changing trajectory with different pruning sparsities in fig:prune-tradeoff. achieves superior inference speedup and less inference memory consumption than baselines targeting the same task performance. Compared to the LoRA+Prune baseline, when pruning RoBERTa models targeting similar task accuracy, gains 21.8% more inference speedup and 7% more memory reduction. For T5 model pruning with 97% dense model performance maintained, results in 62.7% more inference speedup with 24.8% more inference memory reduced compared to the LoRA+Prune baseline. When pruning large LLaMA2-7B models, prunes gets 6.7% more speedup and 9.2% more inference memory reduction than the LoRA+Prune baseline, with about 85% dense model performance maintained.

We show the further analysis in tab:ablate-distillation to compare the self-distillation technique we use in and traditional knowledge distillation methods. When ablating the dynamic layer mapping strategy in our self-distillation approach, the LM performance decreased by 0.8% with similar training time and memory consumption. When training without distillation objectives (w/o self-distillation), the LM performance drops by 1.7%. Nonetheless, the training is slightly faster with less memory costs. These results present that using distillation objectives for better LM task performance will sacrifice training efficiency as a tradeoff. Furthermore, we also demonstrate the comparisons with existing static knowledge distillation strategies, using the converged full-parameter fine-tuned LM (FT teacher) and LoRA-tuned LM (LoRA teacher) as the teacher model. We calculate the time consumption for both teacher and student training when using these distillation baselines. As shown in tab:ablate-distillation, using fully fine-tuned models as the teacher will incur more memory cost than dense model fine-tuning, while only consumes 70%. In the meantime, the training convergence speed of training is two times faster than the traditional knowledge distillation method with a fine-tuned teacher. Furthermore, using a LoRA-tuned model as the teacher will result in extremely slow training speed. In addition, simply tuning the LoRA layers with knowledge distillation objectives doesn't help reduce the training memory consumption, as the memory consumption is still 96.1% than full fine-tuning.

Effects of adaptive tuning strategies on end-task performance and training efficiency. As the trajectories shown in fig:rank-tradeoff, simply enlarging the initial tuning parameter number in will not improve or even hurt the model's final performance. Moreover, the training memory consumption grows even higher than fine-tuning when the tuning layer ranks become extremely large (initial ranks set as 256). Therefore, this result proves that adding tuning parameters according to layer salience is better than uniformly increasing them before tuning.

Effects of early pruning on task accuracy and training memory in LLaMA pruning. fig:llama-init-tradeoff shows the effect of the initial density on LLaMA models' task performance under the 30% sparsity pruning setting. We find that densely-trained models only perform better in TruthfulQA with fewer parameters pruned before tuning. The accuracy reaches 48.6 and 47.4 when not pruning before tuning, compared to 46.6 and 44.7 when directly pruning to the target sparsity for both 7B and 13B models. Training the LM densely harms the model performance while costing extra memory for all other tasks. These results demonstrate that pruning during training hurts large LM performance under distillation-free settings, and we hypothesize this is due to the training instability issue when parameters are set to zeros during fine-tuning.

We report the raw efficiency evaluation results in tab:raw-efficiency and tab:raw-llama-efficiency, including training and inference time and memory consumption. The training times are measured in seconds, and the inference times are measured in milliseconds. All memory footprints are measured in MB. We report the time-to-accuracy for RoBERTa and T5 model training to measure the training time. For LLaMA model training, we measure the training time per epoch to represent training time consumption.

\begin{split}
S(H, i) &= \sum _l \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial H(X)_{i,l}} \cdot H(X)_{i,l} \\
&= \sum _p \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial W_{i,p}} \cdot W_{i,p} \\
&+ s\cdot \sum _q \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial {W_B}_{i,q}} \cdot {W_B}_{i,q} \\
S(H, j) &= \sum _l \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial X_{j,l}} \cdot X_{j,l} \\
&= \sum _p \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial W_{p,j}} \cdot W_{p,j} \\
&+ s\cdot \sum _q \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial {W_A}_{q,j}} \cdot {W_A}_{q,j} \\
S(H, k) &= s\cdot \sum _l \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial {W_A}_{k,l}} \cdot {W_A}_{k,l} \\
&= s\cdot \sum _l \frac{\partial \mathcal {L}(x, y | \Theta )}{\partial {W_B}_{l,k}} \cdot {W_B}_{l,k} \\
\end{split}

FIGREF1.text: provides both training and inference efficiency benefits by pruning and tuning pretrained LM parameters adaptively via the adapter. We dynamically adjust (add/reduce) adapter input/output dimensions and the rank (r apt ). Reducing adapter dimensions prunes frozen parameters, making training and inference faster and more memory-efficient. Adding adapter ranks helps recover the pruned LM's task performance. In contrast, existing adapters like LoRA allow efficient training but do not provide inference efficiency since the model size is not reduced.

FIGREF7.text: adaptively identifies pruning and tuning parameters via APT adapters during fine-tuning with little cost. gradually prunes LM parameters with binary pruning masks learned from our lightweight outlier-aware salience scoring function for training and inference efficiency. also adds tuning parameters in salient layers in LM fine-tuning through increasing dynamic ranks in APT adapters for performance recovery.
